page.title: 16GREAT MEOLS "SUNKEN FOREST"
page.content: On the coast of Meols is a{submerged {forest}which has been seen at times. During the latter half of the Nineteenth Century and the early part of the Twentieth,between the tides the forest beds were a well known feature on the N.Coast of the peninsula.It has attracted scientists and naturalists. The forest beds are the sad remains of land drowned by a rise in sea-level after the {Ice Age. 5000 years ago,in contrast to the man- made landscape of pasture,crops and habitations,this part of{Wirral}was a dense forest. Pollen of Elm and Alder are found in large numbers in the{Dove {Point}peat;Hazel and Buckthorn also being common. The ancient woods remained until early farming communities began clearing the land for crops and animals about 5000 years ago.
